text: Hey, what's up creators and welcome back
to the first hour of Unreal Engine
course. In this video, I'm going to be
introducing you to enhanced input action
mappings in Unreal Engine. This system
is going to be key to setting up your
key bindings for your game. Now, what I
mean by that is these input action
mappings is essentially going to be what
allows you to tell Unreal Engine to do
something when they press a button on
their keyboard or their controller. So,
inside of Unreal Engine, we use this
system and we use two things. We use
input actions which are essentially the
trigger and then we also have our
mapping context which are essentially
our collection of which of those
triggers are available at a given time.
Let's jump straight into Unreal Engine
and show you how you can set these up
and how it's all going to work in the
context of our flashlight system. Okay,
so now that we're inside of Unreal
Engine, let's talk about the way that
Unreal Engine is going to handle those
inputs. It does that using something
called enhanced input actions. So with
all of this, these are really
straightforward for us to set up. Let's
take a look at this and go through the
demo of doing it for our flashlight that
we created. So if we go to our content
drawer inside of here, if we go to
content, we can see we've got a folder
called input. Inside of here we have a
folder for actions.
And then we also have a input mapping
context as well. Let me try and explain
these. An input mapping context is
essentially going to be a collection of
all of your different input types that
you're going to have. So you can see
while I've got this open, you can see
I've got mappings for jump, move, and
look. This context is just a collection
and it just tells Unreal Engine which
mappings need to be active at a given
time.
Then you also have if I close this you
have your actions folder and you have
your input actions. Again we can see
we've got jump, look, mouse look, move.
These actions actually contain the way
that these should respond in terms of
should it be a pressed input, should it
be a released input, um, and also what
key should be activating these as well.
That being said, let's go ahead and set
all of this up for ourselves for our
flashlight so all of this makes sense.
So the very first thing that we're going
to do inside of here is we are going to
create a new input action mapping. To do
that, we are going to go into this input
folder, actions, and then if we right
click in here, go to input. What we're
going to be creating is an input action.
Like I said, this is just going to
control how that input should be
received. So, I'm going to give this a
name a
flash toggle. the I a just being the
naming prefix that we're using for these
input actions.
Then I'm going to go ahead and double
click on this to open it up. Inside of
here, we can see we've got a couple of
different settings. First things first,
we've got things like a description. I
would definitely recommend that you make
these so that when other developers are
working in your project or let's say
you're coming back after a long time,
you are going to know what each of these
are going to do. I'm just going to give
this the name flashlight toggle
input.
And that's just a description for me for
later on. Then you have got things
inside of here such as triggers,
modifiers, and so on. I'm going to add a
new trigger. And with these triggers, I
can now go into here and I can choose
one. Now, the way we're going to be
setting up this input action mapping is
we're going to make this execute when
you press a button. That button being F.
But for us, we just need to make sure we
set this up for pressed.
And then once we've done that, that's
everything we need to do inside of here.
We're going to be actually setting the
key binding within the context, which
will make sense in a moment. But now I
just want you to know this input action
is just there to determine the type of
input that this should be.
With that done, I want you to go ahead
and save it in the top lefthand corner.
Then if we go back to our content
drawer, we can now go back to that input
folder and we can open up our input
mapping context. There is already one of
these in place. So we're just going to
be adding on to what is there already.
You can see inside of here, this context
already has jump, move, and look
enabled. We're going to add another
mapping by pressing the plus icon here.
And then we should be able to find in
our list our flash toggle that we
created earlier on. So now that we have
done this and added that mapping, it is
now in the context. So when we go to
write our blueprint code, we're actually
going to be able to write code that
responds to this. But as of right now,
we've not actually told it which key it
should respond to. So what I'm going to
do is go to my flash toggle and I'm
going to expand this. You can see now it
has added a key value here. And all I
have to do now is just choose which key
it should respond to.
I'm going to go to keyboard and then I
can choose any letter or number or
anything on the keyboard really.
Just to make this easy, I'm going to
make this respond to the letter F on the
keyboard. So, it's just F for toggle. If
you can't find it too easily, you can
either go through the list or you can
just search for it by pressing F on the
keyboard in the search here.
Perfect. Once that's done, we now have
our input action fully set up and we're
able to attach code to whenever the
player actually presses F on the
keyboard. So that's it. We're now at a

Unreal Engine is going to be listening
